cab.content: [This Document is the Property of His Britannic Majesty's Government. ]Printed for the Cabinet. February 1924.SECRET.CP. 97 (24). ICABINET.PROPOSED IMPERIAL ECONOMIC COMMITTEE. Memorandum by the Secretary of State for the Colonies-. I HAVE had some preliminary discussion on this with the Chancellor of theExchequer and the President of the Board of Trade, and I was at first inclined to share the view that it would be desirable to accept the recommendation of the ImperialEconomic Conference (Cmd. 1990, pp. 18-19) that a standing Economic Committeeshould be set up. I have, however, subsequently had an opportunity of reading the discussions atthe Conference, and particularly the objections taken (see Cmd. 2009, pp. 573-4) hythe Canadian representative (Mr. Graham), and I have now come to the definite conclusion that it would be unwise to proceed with the establishment of a committee with a general reference such as that contemplated by the Conference. I feel that such a body would, almost inevitably, become either completelyineffective or else politically dangerous. At the same time, I suggest that the Government, if it decides not to proceedwith the proposal for a standing Economic Committee, should make it quite clear thatit would welcome the establishment of ad hoc Committees, on which all or some ofthe Dominion Governments would be represented, as well as His Majesty's Government,to consider any questions or groups of questions which were agreed by the Govern-ments concerned to require co-operation in enquiry with a view to action. J. H. T. Colonial Office, February 9, 1924.11219]
